My Afternoons with Margueritte

Saccharine, cloying, nauseating, are just a few of the disparaging phrases which come to mind when attempting to describe Jean Becker's newest venture

Band of the Week: Rotary Connection

By James Bithell

Resident sound-nerd <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> thumbs through reams of musty vinyl so you don't have to. Here are his weekly recommendations...

Couldn't Ask For Another

There is no doubt that Rose Rea and Charles Rivington's production Couldn't Ask For Another is a sophisticated and successful endeavour

Happily Ever After Society presents: Return to the Forbidden Planet

Return to the Forbidden Planet written by Bob Carlton, touched down in York's own Central Hall last night, for the first of three performances by Happily Ever After Society

Another Year

Mike Leigh's work in film for the past twenty years constitutes a significant oeuvre, and for those who argue that his most recent work is tied a little too strongly to either period drama (<em>Vera Drake</em>, <em>Topsy-Turvy</em>) or a cinema of unvarying mood (<em>All or Nothing</em>, <em>Happy-Go-Lucky</em>), they'll find that <em>Another Year</em> is a rich masterpiece - like <em>Secrets & Lies</em>, it's a great introduction to what Leigh does best

Starry Eyed: The Nouse Constellations Guide

By James Bithell

Leeds has already been fairly generous with its smaller festivals this year; Live at Leeds and the British Wildlife Festival were both over-egged puddings with so many crucial acts squeezed into such cosy events that clashes occurred with pretty much any band you saw.

Let Me In

Remakes are risky business in pretty much any context. Occasionally, they end up being better than their source material, a perfect example being Terry Gilliam's borrowing of the themes and style of <em>La Jetee</em> to create <em>Twelve Monkeys</em>, a veritable masterpiece of modern cinema

Band of the Week: The Monks

By James Bithell

Resident sound-nerd <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> thumbs through reams of musty vinyl so you don't have to. Here are his weekly recommendations...

Burke and Hare

John Landis is perhaps best known for formidable cult classics <em>The Blues Brothers</em>, and <em>An American Werewolf in London</em>, as well as a stream of commercial movies in the seventies and eighties. Burke and Hare, however, is the first film he has directed in twelve years. He seems to have gotten a little rusty...

The Roar of the Greasepaint, The Smell of the Crowd

Full of insightful messages, belting songs, and often useless, but amusing, anecdotes, the Drama Barn's latest production <em>The Roar of the Greasepaint and the Smell of the Crowd</em> written by Leslie Bricusse and Anthony Newley, got off to a great start last night

The Kids Are All Right

I'm not surprised that there's already Oscar buzz surrounding this film. Annette Bening and Julianne Moore create some stunning moments, and both of them might easily be in the running for a couple of gongs come awards season

Frieze

Frieze Art Fair, in eight years, has become a leading fixture in the art world's annual calendar. Every October, over 150 of the most dynamic contemporary art galleries from 29 countries gather in Regent's Park, London, to show over 1000 artists' work (Thumbnail credit Frieze Art Fair 2010, courtesy of Linda Nylind for Frieze)

Saw 3D

Rarely is a sequel better than the original film - but a sixth sequel? Well, let's just say it would have to be superb, and <em>Saw 3D</em> (chronologically, <em>Saw VII</em>) is anything but

The Intolerable Interment of Ignatius Briary

'Student written' is a term that, perhaps unfairly, has become synonymous in many people's minds with self-indulgent and over-ambitious. However seasoned writer and director Max Tyler's latest play, <em>The Intolerable Interment of Ignatius Briary</em>, is neither of the above

Africa United

I promised myself I wouldn't call <em>Africa United</em> - the first feature-length film from director Debs Gardner-Paterson, starring a cast of relative unknowns - the "African <em>Slumdog Millionaire</em>"

Red

In between the releases of heavy literary adaptations <em>The Last Station</em> and <em>The Tempest</em>, Dame Helen Mirren has found herself firing machine guns, sniper rifles and rocket launchers in <em>Red</em>. The value of seeing Queen Elizabeth II put on a menacing expression amidst explosions and shoot-outs manages to be more than just novelty

A pagan adventure

By James Bithell

A <em>MUSE</em> photo feature (Thumbnail credit Photo: Sam Newsome)

The puppet masters of the music industry

Is it all sex, drugs and rock and roll? Do stars make the music business, or is it the other way around? Oliver Trotman speaks to band manager Dick O'Dell and discovers what drives one of the most popular, competitive and profitable industries (Thumbnail credit Natasha Khan of Bat For Lashes)

Children of the revolution?

Students have a reputation of rebelling against the system. Mia de Graaf looks at the history of student politics and exercising the right to make your voice heard (Thumbnail credit Warwick students protest in 1975. Photo: Jake Bernard)

Dead man walking

The death penalty is always an issue that provokes debate. But Camilla Apcar questions its worth after speaking to a man exonerated after 19 years on death row (Thumbnail credit Inside an American prison. Photo credit: Jake Bernard)

Coming up for air

By James Bithell

Stephen Gill's photography reflects a wide range of interests, from birds, animals and music. Lowenna Waters speaks to this most contemporary of artists (Thumbnail credit Some of Gill's work. All images credit: Stephen Gill photography)

Social pariah: Charlotte Hogarth-Jones

Mecca Bingo. It's the experience of a lifetime, and I don't think I've been more excited in my whole entire life (Thumbnail credit Justyn Hardcastle)

Camilla Jenkins

To quote the infamous MJ: "this is it." Nine editions, three supplements, countless photo shoots, an NUS nomination and now it's over. That is not to mention the numerous tears, exhaustion and angry words that come with working in a high pressured environment

Halloween by numbers

Halloween by numbers

MUSE: 26 October 2010

Never ones to leave a party without the appropriately dramatic exit, we saw no reason why this edition should be anything less than spectacular (Thumbnail credit George Lowther)

Shopping Habits

By James Bithell

Krupa Solanki explores how the new spending cuts will affect our shopping habits (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: style.com)

Sofia Redgrave

Ever heard of Anna Dello Russo? Natalie Hartley? These women are fronting a new phenomenon which is tackling our celebrity obsessed culture head on, moving away from the polished 'style icon' (think Cheryl Cole or Posh) to the people who actually know a little about fashion, and how to wear clothes

Ones to Watch: Where are they now?

By James Bithell

The <em>Nouse</em> Fashion team look back at where they got it right ... and wrong (Thumbnail credit Rosie Huntington-Whiteley)

Granny Shoppers

By James Bithell

Sarah Barratt, an artist from the Norman Rea Galley, talks to Beth Walton about her 'Granny Shoppers'

Lowenna Waters

Finally, the funding cuts have been announced, and the arts have not fared as badly as they could have done
